articles.headline: Intervention Is Bold, but Has a Basis in History
articles.snippet: The government’s plan to take ownership stakes in banks is an exceptional step, but is is not unprecedented.
articles.abstract: The government’s plan to take ownership stakes in banks is an exceptional step, but is is not unprecedented.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a week of mounting chaos in financial markets around the globe, the United States took a momentous step that shifts power in the economy toward Washington and away from Wall Street.

articles.headline: Commodity Prices Tumble
articles.snippet: The financial panic and economic slowdown have put at least a temporary end to the commodity bull market of the last seven years.
articles.abstract: The financial panic and economic slowdown have put at least a temporary end to the commodity bull market of the last seven years.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  The global financial panic and the economic slowdown have put at least a temporary end to the commodity bull market of the last seven years, sending prices tumbling for many of the raw ingredients of the world economy.

articles.headline: Obama Details Plan to Aid Victims of Fiscal Crisis
articles.snippet: Barack Obama called for temporary but costly new programs to aid employers, automakers, homeowners, the unemployed, and state and local governments.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama called for temporary but costly new programs to aid employers, automakers, homeowners, the unemployed, and state and local governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio  Senator Barack Obama proposed new steps on Monday to address the economic crisis, calling for temporary but costly new programs to help employers, automakers, homeowners, the unemployed, and state and local governments.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Quiet Political Shifts as More Blacks Are Elected
articles.snippet: Analysts say black officials at local levels are increasing the ranks of white voters familiar with black leadership.
articles.abstract: Analysts say black officials at local levels are increasing the ranks of white voters familiar with black leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, N.H. — Melanie Levesque grabbed the campaign signs from her Mercedes S.U.V. and plunged into the white crowd at the fairgrounds here. The cows were lowing, the cider presses churning and Mrs. Levesque, a black state legislator, was hunting for votes and a place in history.

articles.headline: High-Flying Hedge Fund Falls Back to Earth
articles.snippet: Thousands of hedge fund managers, mostly young, mostly male and virtually all unknown outside financial circles, confront a sober reality: for now, the days of easy money are over.
articles.abstract: Thousands of hedge fund managers, mostly young, mostly male and virtually all unknown outside financial circles, confront a sober reality: for now, the days of easy money are over.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only 10 months ago, Remy Trafelet was so flush that he treated about 100 employees at his hedge fund to a getaway in Venice. He and his crew spent a long, luxurious weekend at the five-star Hotel Bauer, which has Murano glass chandeliers, private gondoliers and a splendid view of a 17th-century basilica.

articles.headline: Youthful Voice Stirs Challenge to Secular Turks
articles.snippet: In a country that built its modern identity on secularism, the embrace of religious identity is an act of rebellion.
articles.abstract: In a country that built its modern identity on secularism, the embrace of religious identity is an act of rebellion.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL  High school hurt for Havva Yilmaz. She tried out several selves. She ran away. Nothing felt right.

articles.headline: Seeking a Partner at the Dance
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs waltzed Warren Buffett. Morgan Stanley tangoed with the Japanese. Bank of America got down with Merrill Lynch. But Vikram S. Pandit of Citigroup looks like the wallflower.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs waltzed Warren Buffett. Morgan Stanley tangoed with the Japanese. Bank of America got down with Merrill Lynch. But Vikram S. Pandit of Citigroup looks like the wallflower.
articles.lead_paragraph: “As long as the music is playing, you’ve got to get up and dance.”

articles.headline: Thriftiness on Special in Aisle 5
articles.snippet: Several chain stores have concluded that providing information about how to manage a household on a budget can spur loyalty.
articles.abstract: Several chain stores have concluded that providing information about how to manage a household on a budget can spur loyalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home economics, that lost art in which generations of students learned to keep a household going on a tight budget, is making a comeback. Only this time, lessons in pinching pennies are being taught not in the nation’s classrooms but in its stores.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Rosenbloom and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Despite Big Rally, Grim Outlook on Profits and Jobs
articles.snippet: A day after the stock market staged one of its biggest rallies in history, investors retreated once again.
articles.abstract: A day after the stock market staged one of its biggest rallies in history, investors retreated once again.
articles.lead_paragraph: The euphoria that swept Wall Street on Monday gave way to a sober reality on Tuesday: a recession, perhaps the deepest one in decades, may be unavoidable.

articles.headline: Drama Behind a $250 Billion Banking Deal
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary gave little choice to nine major banks but to sell shares to the government.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary gave little choice to nine major banks but to sell shares to the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief executives of the nine largest banks in the United States trooped into a gilded conference room at the Treasury Department at 3 p.m. Monday. To their astonishment, they were each handed a one-page document that said they agreed to sell shares to the government, then Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said they must sign it before they left.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Eric Dash
